name: Basic
summary: Classic LEGO Bricks, Plates, and Tiles can be stacked vertically by attaching the round studs with a small amount of pressure.
description:
Pushing the studs of one brick into the 'anti-studs' of another brick creates a tight connection which is commonly called 'Clutch Power'.

Parts that have additional features will appear in a different category. For example, a brick with a stud facing outward would be in the SNOT category, a plate with a clip will be in the clips category, and a brick with a Technic pin hole will be in the Technic category.

What is 'Clutch Power'? It is the result of an 'Interference fit' between a stud and antistud (the space where a LEGO Stud attaches on the underside of another LEGO Brick). This occurs because a stud is slightly larger than the opening in the underside of a LEGO brick. When you are pushing on the top of a brick to attach it, the stud is forcing the plastic it is touching to deflect slightly.

name: Wall
summary: Panels, walls, doors, and related parts make it easier to construct models than using bricks and plates alone.
description: Most of the parts in this category are taller than one brick. That's why many of the parts are described by three dimensions: Width × Length × Height.

name: SNOT
summary: These parts allow you to attach studs facing outwards (Studs Not On Top) or attach studs at an offset from the normal grid.
description:
SNOT bricks and brackets allow you to attach parts facing outwards. There are other techniques that allow you to attach studs facing outwards, but the parts in this category are designed specifically for this purpose.

We also have jumpers which allow you to offset a part by ½ of the width of a LEGO plate. This is an unusual offset within the LEGO system that makes a lot of interesting techniques possible.

name: Angle
summary: Slopes, wedges, and windscreens allow you to include angled sections in your model.
description: Wedges have an angle relative to the horizontal plane, while slopes and windscreens have an angle relative to a vertical plane.

name: Curve
summary: Build streamlined or organic shapes using a rich palette of curved parts.
description:
Curved parts are organized into subcategories based on the direction of the curve.

Parts curved on the horizontal plane are described as bricks, plates, or cylinders. Parts curved relative to a vertical plane are curved, arch, bow, or mudguards. Parts curved in multiple dimensions are dishes, domes, and wedges.

name: Articulation
summary: Parts that bend or rotate, allowing for a wide range of interesting building techniques.
description: Hinges allow parts to bend on one axis, turntables allow parts to spin in place, joints allow parts to rotate around multiple axes, and rails allow parts to slide on a plane.

name: Clip
summary: Clips can attach to other parts in this category such as a bar, handle, or lightsaber blade.
description:
Clips were introduced in 1978 because they are the same connection type as the hands of the LEGO Minifigure which debuted in that year. This is when we began seeing parts with a 2.4mm diameter handle, as well as minifig accessories (which you will find in another category).

A bar (or lightsaber) can be inserted into parts with a hollow stud. That's because the hole in a hollow stud has the same 2.4mm diameter.

name: Minifig
summary: The classic LEGO Minifigure and Friends Minidoll live in a rich world of clothing, accessories, weapons, and containers.
description:
Minifigures and Minidolls can hold accessories in their hands which are the same diameter as a standard LEGO handle, bar, or clip.

Some Minifigures or Minidolls can even attach tiny accessories to their hair using a tiny bar element.

name: Nature
summary: Elemental forces, foliage, teeth, and tails bring the LEGO world to life.
description:
Some of the parts in this category are both difficult to sort and difficult to name. For example, parts that you might describe as a tail, horn, or vine are difficult to name — you might assume it is a vine when it's green or a horn when it's white.

Nonetheless, this is one of the most fun categories because it includes a lot of organically-shaped parts that can give LEGO models a nicely finished aesthetic.

name: Vehicle
summary: Wheels allow your model to move, brackets make them stronger, noses make them look faster, and tracks give them somewhere to go.
description:
Wheels in this category are sorted by the outer diameter of the hub, rather than the diameter of the tires which vary a good deal.

Everything else is sorted by the type of vehicle parts, such as train track and wheels, rollercoaster track and cars, or STUNTZ ramps and loops.

name: Technic
summary: Technic is a system unto itself, with a focus on connecting parts using pins and axles, but you will find plenty of Technic parts with studs as well.
description:
Modern Technic sets include very few Classic (or 'System') parts containing studs, because they have moved towards an engineering-focused building system that abandons the awkward 5:6 ratio of classic bricks in favor of a 3-dimensional grid based on the width of a plate (5 units).

A large selection of Technic parts with studs remain in production for a completely different reason... Classic 'System-based' LEGO sets have adopted Technic as the primary way to add interactive play features and a critical tool in making models stronger.

It is interesting to see how far Technic has evolved away from the classic Technic brick. In recent years, there has been a push to make Technic sets more realistic, which has resulted in a huge number of Technic 'panel' elements which can give the exterior of the model exactly the right shape. This is especially true in the high-end Technic supercars which need to match the appearance of a complex curved vehicle.

name: Electronics
summary: Add light and motion to your creations using LEGO hubs, motors, lights, and sensors.
description: The current system for connecting electronics to a battery pack or hub is called 'Powered Up'. While there is a basic battery pack that can work with up to two motors, the majority of battery packs are bluetooth-connected hubs which allow you to create programs to control your model.

name: Other
summary: LEGO parts that don't fit very well in other categories.
description: I'm always looking for ways to find a home for these difficult-to-categorize parts. If you have ideas, let me know!

name: DUPLO
summary: The larger bricks for younger kids are twice as big in each direction and compatible with regular LEGO bricks
description:
You can attach a standard LEGO 2×2 or 2×4 brick on top of a DUPLO brick. This allows you to create large models using DUPLO bricks for the core, with standard LEGO bricks covering them up.

Remember, twice as big in each dimension results in a brick that is 8-times as large by volume.

If that's not big enough, there's also the discontinued QUATRO line, which is 4-times the width of a LEGO brick (or 64-times the volume).

name: Brick
summary: A LEGO brick is a rectangular prism with one or more round 'studs' on the top.
description:
The bottom of a LEGO brick features an opening, or 'antistud' which is ever-so-slightly smaller than a stud, causing them to stick together when connected with a small amount of force.

A 1×1 brick has proportions of 5 units wide and 6 units tall. It is 8mm wide (per stud) and 9.6mm tall (excluding the height of the stud).

name: Plate
summary: A LEGO Plate is 1/3 of the height of a LEGO brick.
description: Stacking three plates is equal to the height of a LEGO Brick. (Each plate is 3.2 millimeters tall, excluding the height of the stud.)

name: Blate
summary: At two plates thick, it isn't really a brick or a plate.
description: Some other terms that are sometimes used include 'tall plate', '⅔ tall', or 'shorty'.

name: Tile
summary: A tile is the same thickness as a plate, but has a smooth surface on one side.
description:
Most tiles have a smooth surface on the top, with antistuds on the bottom.

In recent years, we have seen the introduction of "Inverted" tiles which have studs on the top and a smooth surface on the bottom.

name: Baseplate
summary: Baseplates are thin and flexible — much thinner than a standard LEGO Plate.
description:
Their most iconic modern usage is as the foundation for sets in the Modular Building Series.

Be careful, baseplates can be damaged more easily than other LEGO parts because they are so large and so flexible — If you bend it too far, it will break!

name: 1× Brick
summary: Bricks that are 1-stud wide.
description: This includes corner parts that are 1-stud thick and help you build stronger models.

name: 2× Brick
summary: Bricks that are 2-studs wide.
description: This includes arguably the most iconic LEGO element of all, the classic 2×4 Brick (Part 3001).

name: Tall Brick
summary: Bricks that are taller than a standard LEGO brick.
description: There is some debate in the LEGO community about whether these parts are strictly necessary since you can build them by stacking regular LEGO Bricks. That said, they are very popular in sets (especially sets aimed at younger builders), and they make it a lot easier to build large models.

name: Hollow Brick
summary: Bricks that are hollow because they do not have a bottom tube.
description: These hollow bricks come almost exclusively in translucent plastic. It is hollow because removing the bottom tube makes them easier to see through!

name: 1× Plate
summary: Plates that are 1-stud wide.
description: This includes corner, cross, and cutout parts with a 1-stud border.

name: 2× Plate
summary: Plates that are 2-studs wide.

name: Large Plate
summary: Plates that are 3 or more studs wide.

name: Other Plate
summary: Basic plates that are modified in a small way, such as a smooth section without studs.

name: 1× Tile
summary: Tiles that are just 1-stud wide.

name: 2× Tile
summary: Tiles that are 2-studs wide.

name: Large Tile
summary: Tiles that are more than two studs wide.

name: Inverted Tile
summary: Tiles that are smooth on the bottom and have studs on top.

name: Window and Door
summary: Windows, doors, and their matching frames.
description: Sizes for windows and doors are based on the size of the frame that they snap into. Since the frame is about 1/5 of the width of a stud, the actual window or door is slightly smaller than the listed dimensions.

name: Fence
summary: A selection of fences (without studs on top) and railings (with studs on top).

name: Decorative
summary: Parts with a textured exterior mimicking stone, brick, wood, or grilles.

name: Stairs
summary: Purpose-built pieces to add a staircase to your model.

name: Panel
summary: Panels are thin parts with just one wall.
description: Many larger panels have studs on top, which allow you to build larger models with fewer bricks and more space inside. Smaller panels are great for adding fine details to a model.

name: Brick
summary: A SNOT brick has one or more outward-facing studs on the side.
description: The outward facing studs on many SNOT bricks are hollow, which allows you to attach a Bar element inside the hole. This is another connection type which you can use to build better models.

name: Bracket
summary: Brackets are SNOT parts that are thinner than a brick.
description: They often have a section that extends beyond the edge of a plate where the outward-facing studs are located.

name: Jumper
summary: Jumpers offer a 1/2 stud offset in one or both directions.
description:
Due to the unusual 5:6 ratio of a LEGO Brick, this shift of ½ the width of a plate works out to 1¼ of the thickness of a plate.

The ability to create offsets that are a fraction of a plate in size makes Jumpers very useful. It also makes them very frustrating as they can result in small gaps that are hard to fill.

name: Slope
summary: Slopes have an angle along a vertical axis.
description: Slopes come in a wide range of angles, including a selection of inverted slopes as well. They are most commonly used to create a sloping roof for a building.

name: Windscreen
summary: A windscreen is a panel that is sloped on a vertical axis.
description: Windscreens are sloped elements with only a single layer of plastic that usually come in transparent or translucent materials. They could also be called "Sloped Panels".

name: Wedge
summary: A brick or plate that is sloped on the horizontal axis.
description: Wedges have an angle along the bottom surface and are often used for wings of an airplane or spaceship.

name: 10-30° Slope
summary: There are only a few sloped parts with these very shallow angles.

name: 33° Slope
summary: This angle is most commonly found in the popular 3× slope bricks.

name: 45° Slope
summary: The most common angle for sloped LEGO elements, as popularized by 2× slope bricks.

name: 55-75° Slope
summary: These are very steep sloped elements which are taller than a single brick.

name: Inverted Slope
summary: A selection of inverted slopes are also available. Most are inverted versions of other sloped elements.

name: 45° Wedge Plate
summary: Wedge Plates with a 45° angle

name: 63° Wedge Plate
summary: The 63° angle is the result of cutting off a section with a 1:2 ratio.

name: 72° Wedge Plate
summary: The 72° angle is the result of cutting off a section with a 1:3 ratio.

name: 76° Wedge Plate
summary: The 76° angle is the result of cutting off a section with a 1:4 ratio.

name: 80° Wedge Plate
summary: The 80° angle is the result of cutting off a section with a 1:6 ratio.

name: Other Wedge Plates
summary: Wedge plates with compound angles and plates with studs positioned at multiple angles.
description: Plates with studs in multiple directions function as hinges that are stuck at a specific angle.

name: Wedge Tile
summary: Smooth tiles with an angled or wedge shape.

name: Wedge Nose
summary: Parts with compound angles that combine attributes of a wedge and a slope in a single piece.

name: Wedge Nose, Inverted
summary: Parts which combine an inverted slope and a wedge shape.

name: Wedge Brick
summary: Bricks with one or more angled corners.

name: Curved Brick
summary: Bricks which are curved along the horizontal plane.
description: They might be completely round or have just a single curved corner.

name: Curved Plate
summary: Plates that are curved on a horizontal plane.
description: They might be completely round or have just a single curved corner.

name: Curved Blate
summary: Blates which are curved along a horizontal plane.
description:
They might be completely round or have just a single curved corner.

Blates are two-plates thick — not quite a brick and not quite a plate.

name: Curved Tile
summary: Tiles which are curved along a horizontal plane.

name: Cylinder
summary: Cylinders have just one wall and are curved relative to a horizontal plane.
description:
Cylinders can also be described as Curved Panels.

Most cylinders parts are more than one brick tall. Just like Panels, some have studs on the top and some do not.

name: Cone
summary: Cones have a circular base and come to a point on the top.
description: Most LEGO cones are truncated because they have a flat area on top with studs.

name: Dish and Dome
summary: Dishes and domes are curved elements that look like the top of a sphere.
description: Dishes are shallow curved shapes whereas domes are the top half of a sphere.

name: Ball
summary: Balls are spheres made out of LEGO.
description: The soccer ball is famous amongst LEGO enthusiasts because "Great Ball Contraptions" lift, grab and roll hundreds of these balls in a big loop around a large table.

name: Curved
summary: These parts are curved on a single vertical axis.
description: They look like part of a circle or ellipse when viewed from the side.

name: Arch and Bow
summary: An arch is a curve that spans an opening, and a bow is half of an arch.
description:
In an architectural context, an Arch can bear a lot of weight by directing force down to the base of the arch.

A Bow is half of an arch — so you can use two of them to create a full arch or use just one for branches of a tree or other curved creations.

name: Wedge
summary: Curved wedges are curved on multiple axes at the same time.
description: Having curves on multiple dimensions results in a very dynamic shape that is useful in building cars or creatures.

name: Mudguard
summary: Mudguards are curved on a vertical plane and often found around wheels on a vehicle.
description: While originally intended to go around wheels when building vehicles, they are also great for curved windows and more.

name: Heart and Star
summary: A selection of parts that are shaped like a ❤️ or a ⭐.
description: While parts shaped like a Star wouldn't normally qualify as curved, most of them are very small and have a round base.

name: Other Curved Parts
summary: Other curved parts which do not fit well in any other category.

name: 1Ø Curved
summary: A collection of (Double) Curves with a 1-stud diameter when viewed from the side.

name: 2×⅔ Curved
summary: Parts that have a curve that goes up 2/3 of a brick in the distance of 2-studs.
description:
You can approximate a circle using 8 of these curves with two on each side and a SNOT brick on the corners.

The actual radius is at-least 7 studs, but I need to do some math to confirm.

name: 3×1 Curve
summary: Parts that have a curve that goes up the height of one brick in the distance of 3-studs.

name: 4×1 Curve
summary: Parts that have a curve that goes up the height of one brick in the distance of 4-studs.

name: 8×1 Curved
summary: Parts that have a curve that goes up the height of one brick in the distance of 8-studs.

name: 1×1 Curved
summary: Parts that have a curve that goes up the height of one brick in the distance of 1-stud.

name: 2×2 Curved
summary: Parts that have a curve that goes up the height of 2-bricks in the distance of 2-studs.

name: Inverted Curve
summary: Parts with a curve along the bottom edge.

name: Other Curved
summary: Curved parts with a different radius, or other less common attributes.

name: Curved Panel
summary: Panel elements that are curved.

name: Hinge
summary: Hinges, click-hinges, and turntables allow you to connect LEGO parts at angles along a single axis.
description:
Many parts in the clip category can also be used to position parts at an arbitrary angle. Click-hinges are stronger but can only be positioned in 22½° increments.

Joints are a separate category because they allow parts to rotate on multiple axes at the same time.

name: Joint
summary: The larger 'ball' and smaller 'towball' connections can be used to attach parts at any angle.
description:
These parts are especially useful for building organic forms, since they can be posed in a wide range of positions.

I have heard from several LEGO Masters contestants that the smaller towball parts often ran out in the brick pit.

name: Click-Socket
summary: The click-socket is a very strong angular connection.
description: The socket uses a Technic pin in the center and teeth around the sides. It can be positioned in 15° increments.

name: Rail and Groove
summary: These parts are often used to add visual texture to a model by adding horizontal or vertical lines, but they can also be used to allow parts to slide horizontally or vertically.

name: Flexible
summary: Flexible plastic elements, cord or fabric
description: Flex Tube is one of the most famous examples, although it is difficult to inventory because it comes in many different lengths, all of which have different part numbers. It is sometimes cut to custom lengths in official sets and when creating MOCs.

name: Smooth
summary: Parts which can turn to any angle on a single axis.
description: Their ability to bend to any angle without stopping at specific angles is what differentiates these parts from 'Click Hinges'.

name: Click-Hinge
summary: A stronger type of hinge that click into place at specific angles.
description: Click-hinges are much stronger than other types of hinges, but have notches that only allow them to be positioned in 22½° increments. (This results in four possible positions between 0° and 90°.)

name: Turntable
summary: Turntables allow you to rotate parts on a horizontal plane.
description: Most Turntables can rotate freely, while 4×4 Turntable Base (part 61435) wants to stop at specific angles.

name: Towball Joint
summary: A small ball and matching socket that allows you to position parts at any angle.
description:
Their small size and ability to build organic shapes makes them especially popular when building realistic models of nature.

One challenge people sometimes face is that the connection is only so strong, which is why they are best suited to relatively small models or smaller details on larger models.

name: Ball Joint
summary: A larger ball and socket that is significantly stronger than a towball Joint.
description:
The ball connection was introduced in the 2011 Hero Factory series, which preceded Bionicle which became the most popular posable figure product line in The LEGO Group's history. Posable figures relying on this connection are also referred to as CCBS for "Character and Creature Building System".

The large ball is sometimes referred to as the 'Voodoo Ball' which is the official name used by The LEGO Group for Technic Ball Joint (part 32474). That's because the part was created while they were designing the first Bionicle sets, which went under the codename 'Bone-Heads of Voodoo Island'.

name: Chain
summary: Plastic chain comprising individual links

name: Flex Axles
summary: While the middle of this part has the x-shaped profile of a Technic Axle, the bar connection on either end is used to attach this to other LEGO parts.
description: They are also referred to as Soft Axle or Axle Hose.

name: Ribbed Hose
summary: Flexible hose with ribs
description: The inner diameter of the ribbed hose fits snugly over a Technic axle.

name: Flex Tube
summary: A fairly rigid but flexible tube
description: Flex Tube the same diameter as a Bar/Handle. Confusingly, it is also sometimes referred to as 'Hose Rigid'.

name: Pneumatic Hose
summary: A very flexible tube to attach pneumatic components
description: It is slightly larger diameter than 'Flex Tube', which means that you can not easily attach a clip to the tube.

name: Flex Cable & Hose
summary: Other flexible LEGO elements

name: String
summary: Thin string and cord.
description: Some have plastic studs on the ends and some require that you attach it using a knot.

name: Band & Belt
summary: Flexible rubber bands and belts

name: Bracelet
summary: Flexible parts with studs made from a stretchy material

name: Plate
summary: Plates with one or more click-hinge connection.

name: Brick
summary: Bricks with one or more click-hinge connection.

name: Click Other
summary: Other parts that use the click-hinge connection.

name: Bar
summary: A cylindrical part that can be grabbed with a clip or inserted into a hollow stud.

name: Clip
summary: A c-shaped part which can firmly grasp a bar or handle.
description:
A minifigure's hand has the same inner dimensions as a clip and can grasp the same parts.

In addition to grasping Bars and Handles, a minifigure hand or clip can hold onto minifig accessories, as well as the side of a tile. (Most commonly a printed 1×2 or 2×2 tile.)

name: Handle
summary: A handle is a bar element that is closed on one or both ends.
description: The central section of a Handle can be grasped by a clip, and handles with an exposed end can be attached to a hollow stud.

name: Flag
summary: Most flags attach to a bar or handle with one or more clip.

name: Door
summary: A few doors use a bar and clip system.
description: Most doors snap into a matching doorframe, and you will find them in the 'Wall' category.

name: Ladder & Railing
summary: Ladders and railings that have the right diameter for a clip to attach to them.

name: Minifigure
summary: Head, torso, and legs to create a classic LEGO Minifigure.
description: Hair and many accessories are interchangeable between Minifigures and Minidolls so they have their own categories.

name: Minidoll
summary: Head, torso, and legs required to build a Minidoll. (Minidolls were introduced in 2012 with LEGO Friends.)
description:
Minidolls are slightly taller than Minifigures and feature more realistic proportions. The tradeoff is that their legs do not move independently, and their hands do not turn.

Hair and many accessories are interchangeable between Minifigures and Minidolls so they have their own categories.

name: Nanofig
summary: Human figures that are smaller than a Minifigure or Minidoll.
description:
The Microfig has a scale of around 1:80 and the Trophy fig has a scale of around 1:130.

Learn more at https://brickarchitect.com/scale/

name: Animal
summary: A wide range of animals are available to liven up your creations.
description: It is worth noting that animals designed for themes like LEGO City which is populated by Minifigures are blockier than those designed for LEGO Friends which tend to be rounder and have a more cartoonish pose.

name: Food & Drink
summary: A plethora of food prep and dining options for Minifigures and Minidolls.

name: Tools
summary: A selection of tools and equipment that LEGO Minifigs and Minidolls need to take care of their respective realms.

name: Footwear
summary: Minifigs are on the move with these parts that attach to their feet.

name: Clothing
summary: It's a good idea to protect your plastic body.

name: Hat & Hair Accessories
summary: Small accessories that connect to tiny holes on some hats and hair parts.

name: Transportation
summary: It's easier to get around LEGO City when you have some wheels.

name: Container
summary: Small Minifig-scale containers that are often used to store food or other accessories.
description: The Treasure chest which debuted in 1989’s LEGO Pirates theme is probably the most iconic of these Minifigure-scale containers.

name: Weapon
summary: When conflict arises in the LEGO universe, you might need one of these.

name: Hair
summary: Hair for Minifigures and Minidolls.

name: Robot
summary: Parts that are almost exclusively used for Robots or Droids.

name: Torso
summary: There are four Minidoll torsos representing a girl, boy, woman, and man.
description: There are also variations introduced for limb differences, such as Autumn from the LEGO Friends reboot in 2023.

name: Skirts & Dresses
summary: This includes skirts, dresses, and ball gowns.

name: Pants & Shorts
summary: A variety of bifurcated garments for Minidolls.

name: Produce
summary: Fruits and Vegetables.

name: Plants
summary: Leaves, vines, ferns and small trees bring the LEGO universe to life.

name: Flowers
summary: There is a lot blooming in LEGO City thanks to this selection of flower elements and stems which hold them.
description: The flower stems have a ‘mini bar’ on the end, which is the same diameter as accessories that attach to Minifigure hats to hair.

name: Elemental
summary: Fire, Water, Wind, Ice, and Stone.

name: Tooth
summary: A selection of teeth to give your models some bite.

name: Barb, Horn, & Tail
summary: Other natural elements including horns, tails, webs, shells and wings.

name: Web
summary: Spider Webs and Strands

name: Wheel
summary: You can get wheels with matching tires, as well as wheels with integrated tires. They are organized by the diameter of the Wheel.
description:
Because they are organized by the wheel diameter instead of the tire diameter, you may want to look in multiple categories to find parts with a specific tire diameter.

That's because a large wheel with a low-profile tire might have a smaller overall radius than a smaller wheel with a balloon-style tire.

name: Wheel Pin
summary: A much smaller 'Pin' connector that is used exclusively with small LEGO wheels. (Larger wheels use Technic Pins and Axles.)
description:
The small 'Wheel Pin' connector is extremely similar to the Technic Pin connection, but it is only about 2LU (3.2mm) wide and 3LU (4.8mm) long.

That's 1/3 narrower and 2/5 shorter than a Technic Pin connector.

name: Bracket & Vehicle Base
summary: Build stronger vehicles more quickly using these bases and brackets.

name: Propeller, Engine, Fin & Mast
summary: Mechanical features of many different kinds of vehicles.

name: Train
summary: Wheels, trucks, and train track.

name: Coaster
summary: Rollercoaster tracks and cars.

name: Stuntz
summary: Ramps and loops in the Stuntz series.

name: Steering
summary: Handlebars and steering wheels.

name: Nose & Roof
summary: Vehicle-specific streamlined shapes and rooves.

name: 8mm
summary: Wheels with an 8mm outer diameter (D.) and the tires that work with them.

name: 11mm
summary: Wheels with an 11mm outer diameter (D.) and tires that work with them.

name: 14mm & 15mm
summary: Wheels with a 14-15mm outer diameter (D.) and tires that work with them.

name: 18mm
summary: Wheels with an 18mm outer diameter (D.) and tires that work with them.

name: 30mm & 30.4mm
summary: Wheels with an 30mm or 30.4mm outer diameter (D.) and tires that work with them.

name: 43.2mm
summary: Wheels with a 43.2mm outer diameter (D.) and tires that work with them.

name: 56mm
summary: Wheels with a 56mm outer diameter (D.) and tires that work with them.

name: Motorcycle
summary: Motorcycle wheels are fairly large but narrow.

name: Integrated Tire
summary: A selection of wheels with an integrated tire.

name: Other Wheels
summary: Wheels with uncommon shapes, sizes and connection types.

name: Brick
summary: Technic bricks have studs, allowing them to integrate with brick-built 'LEGO System' models.

name: Plate
summary: Studded LEGO plates with Technic pin or axle connections.

name: Beam
summary: Studless beams that can be connected using Technic pins and axles.
description: Studless beams began to replace Technic bricks with Studs in the late 90’s, beginning the transition of Technic into a distinct system of building from classic studded LEGO bricks. (Modern Technic sets have very few studded LEGO elements.)

name: Thin Beam
summary: A small selection of 'thin' beams which are ½ of the thickness of a standard LEGO Beam.
description: This is a common proportion within LEGO Technic, but an unusual proportion based on studded LEGO Bricks. A Thin Technic Beam is the same thickness as 1¼ LEGO Plates.

name: Panel
summary: A selection of smooth elements to give Technic models and nicely finished appearance.
description: The LEGO Group has created a huge number of Technic 'Panel' Elements in recent years which can give the exterior of the model exactly the right shape. This is especially true in the high-end Technic Supercars which need to match the appearance of a complex curved vehicle.

name: Connector
summary: A wide range of parts with pin and axle connectors that can be used to connect Technic parts together.
description:
Unlike LEGO bricks which usually have a stud and antistud connection, most Technic parts can not connect with each other without using a separate part to hold them together. These parts are broadly called connectors, with two common connection types.

Axles are held in place with bushings (bush) or using parts with an axle hole connection.

Pins stay put when attached to a pin hole. Smooth pins can rotate freely when attached to a pin hole, whereas friction pins are harder to remove and can not spin very easily.

name: Gears
summary: Bring models to life using gears and racks to create movement.

name: Link & Chain
summary: A selection of parts to transfer power to a different area of the model.

name: Steering
summary: Parts to assist with steering functionality.

name: Engine
summary: Parts to create an engine or implement a shifting system.

name: Mechanical & Pneumatic
summary: Linear motion driven by gears or pneumatics.

name: Other Technic
summary: Balls, propellers, and other hard-to-categorize parts.

name: Flat Panel
summary: Flat panels cover a large area when building Technic models.

name: Curved Panel
summary: Technic panels that are curved on a single axis.

name: Fairing
summary: Technic panels with complex shapes that are curved on multiple axes.
description: The growing popularity of licensed Technic sets based on iconic cars and heavy equipment has required a rich palette of new fairings to faithfully recreate these complex forms.

name: Mudguard
summary: Mudguards are curved openings that typically surround the wheel well of a car or truck.

name: Axle
summary: Standard axles and straight connectors with an axle connector on one end.

name: Pin
summary: Straight connectors with a pin connector.

name: Hub
summary: Connectors that attach parts at an angle.

name: Other Connector
summary: Other connectors with a more complex shape.

name: Hub
summary: Electronics require a hub or battery pack to power the accessories.

name: Motor
summary: LEGO Models come alive using motors with a range of sizes and capabilities.
description:
Powered Up motors can vary greatly in terms of capabilities:

Physical Size, Motor Strength, System vs. Technic connectors, Motor Orientation, Speed Control, Rotation Sensor, Absolute Position, and Zero Position Indicator.

Learn more at https://brickarchitect.com/powered-up/

name: Sensor & Accessories
summary: A selection of sensors and accessories allow you to build more advanced robots and machines.

name: Shooter
summary: LEGO parts that can launch a projectile a short distance.

name: Structural
summary: Structural elements that do not fit well anywhere else.

name: Miscellaneous
summary: One-off parts that defy categorization.

name: Brick
summary: DUPLO bricks are twice as large in all three dimensions than a comparable LEGO brick.

name: Plate
summary: A DUPLO plate is just ½ the height of a DUPLO brick, which makes it the same height as a LEGO Brick.
description: If you need a large, strong base for a LEGO model, you can create a rigid and inexpensive base by using DUPLO plates with a layer of LEGO bricks on top.

name: Angle
summary: DUPLO parts come in a couple of different angles.

name: Curved
summary: DUPLO includes a small selection of curved elements to build more interesting models.

name: Other
summary: Other DUPLO parts that do not fit well anywhere else.
